Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery lekane; white slip; interior, from outside: two black bands; bull walking (only part of horns and muzzle remaining) to right; at right, rump, hind legs with added red and tail of second animal, to right; pendant and rising roundels, elaborate rosettes, lozenges and rosettes as filling ornament; two black bands; maeander pattern; exterior, from outside: goats grazing to right (head and part of foreleg of first, hind leg of second remaining); rising roundel and rosette as filling ornament; maeander running left between pairs of dilute lines; trace of further maeander pattern.
Producer name: Attributed to: Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as produced by the Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl because the decorative style is similar to the style on that bowl (Lemos 1991, 73-4). Lemos describes the far right animal on the interior surface as a bull, however, the hind legs and hoof more closely resemble those of goats and deer. The tail is more difficult to explain as it does not resemble the tails on any other animals including those on bulls.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 74, p. 243, no. 254, pl. 29)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132 note 26)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2056) (phase 2)
